video.title: XOR Multiplication - The Daily Programmer #315
video.description:
The problem from this video can be found here:
https://www.reddit.com/r/dailyprogrammer/comments/6ba9id/20170515_challenge_315_easy_xor_multiplication/

Follow me on twitter: https://twitter.com/CodyLSeibert

topLevelComment.author: Matteo Whitten
topLevelComment.text: what would the code look like if it we were dividing two numbers?

topLevelComment.author: rtnulb
topLevelComment.text: I think the sound is low. Other than that, I was able to follow what you were doing. Thanks.

topLevelComment.author: S
topLevelComment.text: I have no idea what any of this means.

topLevelComment.author: Gurmeet Singh
topLevelComment.text: keep them coming, its like a exercise to the brain

topLevelComment.author: Caja _
topLevelComment.text:
I'm starting to really enjoy these videos. I wake up, get my coffee and watch a video from this series. Pretty good start into the day in my opinion.


Keep it up. :)

topLevelComment.author: ishan mistry
topLevelComment.text: Can  you please tell which Javascript editor are you using ?

replies.author: Yeslyn Casasola
replies.text: Another great editor to use is Atom. It also has a live server.

topLevelComment.author: Andre
topLevelComment.text: 'X' OR as in Exclusive OR, yeah?

replies.author: freeCodeCamp.org
replies.text: I went ahead and removed the [Easy] tag from all the videos in this series.  The [Easy] is part is actually in the title of the challenge name on the subreddit, but it doesn't necessarily mean a beginner would be able to understand it; therefore, it is probably better to just leave it off.

topLevelComment.author: rubicon
topLevelComment.text: Pardon the dumb question, I'm confused what are some of the useful applications for this?

replies.author: YoLninYo
replies.text: Most CPUs can do bitwise operations much faster (they have built low level machine language instructions so the CPU can do it much faster than running through a for loop say) so it's good to know how they work. JS isn't that close to the CPU but concept is the same. You see the real power of bitwise ops in compiled languages like C or C++

replies.author: rubicon
replies.text: freeCodeCamp Thanks! Pretty awesome use cases!

replies.author: freeCodeCamp.org
replies.text:
This is just a programming challenge meant for challenging your programming abilities and expand your knowledge.

Here is a good reference listing just some of the importance of knowing bit-wise operations: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/2096916/real-world-use-cases-of-bitwise-operators.

replies.author: Andre
replies.text: You can use them for enums.
